conbody.p: In order to use Yesod, you're going to need to install it on your system. In addition, you're going to need a Haskell development environment. The recommended approach is to install the Haskell Platform. This will include the Glasgow Haskell Compiler (GHC), Cabal (the package installer, similar to Perl's CPAN or Ruby's Gems) and some core libraries.

Besides the Haskell Platform, there are two other common approaches to getting started with Haskell: downloading GHC directly, and (on Linux) installing from your distribution's package manager. I'm going to advise against these:

ul.li: Yesod is actively tested on the most recent Haskell Platform. We try to make sure it works with other versions of GHC as well, but you may run into issues.
The Haskell Platform includes some utilities (like alex and happy) that are not automatically installed with a normal GHC install.
Most distributions have very out-of-date versions of GHC. At the time of writing, for example, Ubuntu provides GHC 7.0, while the newest GHC is 7.2 (and 7.4 is just around the corner).

conbody.p: One other note: on Linux systems, the Haskell Platform will rely on some system libraries, and without them, you may get some funny error messages. Please make sure you install all the required C libraries. On Debian-based systems, you would need to run:
conbody.codeblock: sudo apt-get install libedit-dev libbsd-dev libgmp3-dev zlib1g-dev freeglut3-dev
conbody.p: Once you have the Haskell Platform installed, it's time to get familiar with Cabal. This utility will automatically resolve dependencies for your packages, download them from Hackage (the package database) and install them. Make sure you have the cabal executable available in your PATH variable, and then you can install Yesod with just two commands:

dlentry.dd: This will download a list of all the packages available on Hackage. You should run this every few days to stay up-to-date.
This will install Yesod and all its dependencies. Go get a cup of coffee.
